State Key Laboratory of Advanced Environmental Technology, Institute of Urban Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences Xiamen 361021 PR China 1 Yuqiu Liu and Xuan Jia contributed equally to this paper. The support effect of sulfated SnO2, TiO2, ZrO2, and SiO2 on FeVO4/CeO2-nanosheet was systematically investigated in this work. Among them, FeVO4/CeO2-nanosheet/sulfated-SnO2 (FeVCe/SSn) catalyst exhibited the widest operating temperature window (227–422 °C) with efficient NO x conversion beyond 90 % and N2 selectivity exceeding 97 %, as well as superior resistance to SO2 and H2O (above 90 % activity retention for 24 h). The catalytic performance followed the order: FeVCe/SSn > FeVCe/STi > FeVCe/SZr > FeVCe/SSi, which aligns well with their redox properties. FeVCe/SSn presents the best redox ability and the second highest surface acidity. Owing to the most pronounced interaction of sulfated SnO2 with FeVO4 and CeO2 nanosheet, surface oxygen vacancies were significantly increased; simultaneously, sulfated SnO2 provided abundant superacidic Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites inherent to SnO2. This synergistic effect enhanced NH3 adsorption/activation and suppressed SO2 adsorption, thereby improving SCR activity and SO2/H2O resistance. The plausible mechanistic studies reveal that the SCR reaction over FeVCe/SSn is governed by a synergistic Eley–Rideal and Langmuir–Hinshelwood pathway. This study demonstrates that the rational design of acid-site density and the interfacial synergy between support and active phase constitute a feasible design principle for SCR catalysts that simultaneously afford a broad temperature window and high SO2/H2O durability. Graphical Abstract Keywords SCR Support effect SnO2 Sulfation CeO2 FeVO4 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia-selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) technology is effective and widely used in fuel combustion for denitrification to minimize the risk of NO x to human and the environment. The commercial V2O5-WO3/TiO2 (VWTi) catalyst, however, only operates efficiently between 300 and 400 °C, precluding its use in low- and medium-temperature windows [1]. Therefore, many efforts are being devoted to developing alternatives that possess both high activity and wide temperature window [2–5]. In a NH3-SCR catalyst, the support with the highest content plays an important role in providing a large specific surface area and surface acidity. More than that, it can interact with the active components, influencing redox ability. These all affect the NO x conversion and H2O/SO2 tolerance of the catalyst. Therefore, it is essential to explore the role of the support during catalyst design [6–8]. Different supports affect the physicochemical properties and catalytic activity of the active phases in SCR catalysts to different degrees, which depend on the properties of carriers and the interacton between support and active components [6]. TiO2, SiO2 and ZrO2 as typical oxide supports have been studied due to their favorable physicochemical properties. TiO2 as the most widely used carrier of NH3-SCR catalysts has a large specific surface aera, plentiful acid sites and a high resistance to sulfur [9,10]. Lin et al. showed that defect-rich TiO2 increases oxygen-vacancy density and improves MnFeO x dispersion, giving excellent low-temperature activity and SO2/H2O durability [11]. Moreover, Jin et al. demonstrated that interfacial V–Ti interaction promotes vanadia dispersion and thereby boosts low-temperature SCR activity [12]. Compared to TiO2, SiO2 is valued for its thermal stability, mechanical strength, high surface area and low cost, as well as abundant acid sites [13,14]. ZrO2 exhibits high structural stability and excellent surface acidity [15]. For instance, mesoporous Cu/ZrO2 catalysts achieve high low-temperature NO x conversion since Cu centers embedded in the ZrO2 lattice enhance NH3 adsorption and redox cycling [16]. Recently, SnO2 has emerged as an alternative support owing to its profuse intrinsic oxygen vacancies and superior hydrothermal stability [17,18]. Zhu et al. synthesized efficient Ce-Nb oxides loaded on SnO2, and the synergy interaction between Sn and Nb species kept both sufficient surface acidity and excellent redox properties after hydrothermal aging [17]. Mostly, the effects of various supports on the catalytic performance of the same active component are different and moreover the rule of support effect changes with the components. For example, when CeO2 is supported on SiO2, γ-Al2O3, ZrO2, and TiO2 seperatedly, the CeO2/γ-Al2O3 catalyst shows the highest activity in NH3-SCR of NO x [6]. However, when W and Ce species were loaded on TiO2, Al2O3 and SiO2, their SCR activity follows the order of CeW > CeWTi > CeWAl > CeWSi at low temperatures, and then TiO2 support performs better than Al2O3 [7]. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, there is still a gap in systematically comparing the support effects of SnO2, TiO2, SiO2 and ZrO2 under identical SCR conditions. Although some surface acid sites are inherent to traditional metal oxide, the acidification treatment of supports still further enhance the SCR activity and anti-poisoning ability [19–21]. Li et al. treated ZrO2 support with sulfuric, phosphoric, nitric, and hydrochloric acids, respectively, and the SCR activity of CeO2/ZrO2 catalyst was improved significantly by sulfuric acid and phosphorylation, especially sulfation. Acid treatment increased its surface acidity largely, especially Brønsted acid sites [22]. Huang et al. hydrolysed TiOSO4 to insert SO4 2- into the TiO2 lattice, creating an interfacially confined MnFe-TOS catalyst; the resulting Mn–O–Fe interaction intensified surface acidity and accelerated NH3 adsorption/reaction [23]. It has been shown that the sulfation of carriers could promote the separation of acid sites and metal sites, improving the adsorption and activation of NH3, O2, and NO, and thus enhancing denitrification efficiency. However, the sulfation effect is highly support-dependent [19,24]. There is still a necessity to compare the sulfation effect of different supports. Therefore, it is new and interesting to study the support effect of the sulfated SnO2, TiO2, ZrO2 and SiO2. The FeVO4/CeO2-nanosheet nanocomposite is a promising SCR catalyst: FeVO4 supplies redox and acid sites, while the CeO2-nanosheet provides rapid oxygen storage/release [25]. However, it is necessary to improve its water and sulfur tolerance and reduce the content of vanadium for the practical applications. Sulfated oxide supports are expected to meet both requirements by modulating surface acidity and metal–support interactions. Herein, FeVO4/CeO2-nanosheet was incorporated on sulfated SnO2, TiO2, ZrO2 and SiO2 to identify the optimal carrier and to correlate sulfate-driven changes in acidity, redox synergy and texture with SCR activity and H2O/SO2 tolerance. The interfacial structure between FeVO4, CeO2 and each sulfated oxide, as well as the dominant Eley–Rideal or Langmuir–Hinshelwood pathway, was elucidated by combined characterization and kinetic tests. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The detailed preparation process of sulfated carriers including TiO2, SiO2, SnO2 and ZrO2 was described in the supplementary material. 10%FeVO4/CeO2-nanosheet was loaded respectively on a series of sulfated carriers with a mass percentage of 15 % including 1.5 wt% FeVO4 and 13.5 wt% CeO2 nanosheets. 0.2087 g Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O and 0.0604 g NH4VO3 were weighed and put in two beakers, respectively. 50 mL of ultrapure water was added into each to dissolve them with stirring. 0.7941 g CeO2 nanosheets (Fig. S1 SEM images) whose preparation procedure was described detailedly in the work [25] and 5.0000 g the corresponding carriers were added into Fe(NO3)3 solution and stirred for 3 h. Then NH4VO3 solution was poured into the above solution under constant stirring at 800 rpm, and then the mixture was stirred continuously for another 3 h. The precipitate was centrifugated and washed with deionized water and then put into an oven, dried at 70 °C for 12 h. Finally, the above samples were calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 5 h and then cooled down to room temperature naturally. The produced samples were named FeVCe/SC including FeVCe/STi, FeVCe/SSi, FeVCe/SSn, FeVCe/SZr, where SC stood for sulfated carriers and C meant Ti, Si, Sn and Zr, abbreviations of TiO2, SiO2, SnO2 and ZrO2 carriers. Applying the same steps, only Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O and NH4VO3 were used to synthesize pure FeVO4 named as FeVO4-P. 10 %FeVO4/CeO2-nanosheet (abbreviated as FeVCe) sample as a control was prepared by the above procedures without carriers. In order to exclude the effect of calcination, the sulfated carriers were calcined at 500 °C for 5 h as FeVCe/SC to obtain the comparison samples denoted as SC-500. 2.2 Catalytic activity test The NH3-SCR of NO x activity test was conducted on a fixed-bed activity evaluation unit, which mainly consisted of a gas distribution system, a gas mixing and preheating system, an SCR reactor, a flue gas analysis system and an exhaust gas treatment system. In each test, 0.6 mL of catalyst sample (40–60 mesh) was placed in the middle of quartz tube (diameter Φ = 6.0 mm). The experimental flue gas included 500 ppm NO x , 500 ppm NH3, 5 vol% O2, 100 ppm SO2 (when used), 5 vol% H2O (when used) and balance gas N2. The total flow rate was 500 mL/min, with a GHSV of 50000 h−1. The components contents of flue gas at the inlet and outlet of the unit were detected by a gas analyzer, Antaris IGS (Thermo Fisher Scientific). NO x conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated as follows. NO x conversion ( % ) = 1 – NO x out NO x in × 100 % N 2 selectivity ( % ) = 1 – 2 N 2 O out NO x in + NH 3 in – NO x out – NH 3 out × 100 % [NO x ]in, [NH3]in, [NO x ]out and [NH3]out mean the inlet and outlet concentrations of NO x (NO + NO2) and NH3, respectively. [N2O]out represents the outlet concentration of N2O. 2.3 Characterizations The detailed descriptions of characterizations are provided in the supplementary material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR performance 3.1.1 NO x conversion and N2 selectivity Fig. 1 demonstrates the NO x conversion and N2 selectivity of FeVCe and FeVCe/SC catalysts at 150–425 ℃. The NO x conversion of FeVCe was higher than that of FeVCe/SC when the temperature was below 250 °C and kept more than 90 % in the temperature range from 175 to 375 °C. Except for FeVCe/SSi sample, the NO x conversion of other FeVCe/SC samples increased to 100 % with the rising temperature, remained 100 % within a certain temperature range, and then decreased after the temperature exceeded 375 or 400 °C. The temperature range (T90) in which the NO x conversion is above 90 % for FeVCe/STi, FeVCe/SSn and FeVCe/SZr was 245–422 °C, 227–422 °C and 253–410 °C, respectively. Among them, FeVCe/SSn catalyst had the widest T90. The N2 selectivity of FeVCe/STi, FeVCe/SSn, FeVCe/SZr and FeVCe maintained at almost 100 % when temperatures were lower than 350 °C, while they decreased to different degrees at temperatures above 350 °C. The N2 selectivity of FeVCe decreased to 93.7 % at 422 °C, while the N2 selectivity of FeVCe/SSn maintained above 97.0 % within the test temperature range. In summary, although the sulfated SnO2, TiO2 and ZrO2 carriers reduced NO x conversions at the low-temperature (< 250 °C) compared with FeVO4/CeO2-nanosheet sample, they significantly enhanced NO x conversions at the mid-temperature (> 325 °C) to different degrees and increased the N2 selectivity. FeVCe/SSn exhibited the best SCR performance among the loaded catalysts. The reported commercial VWTi catalysts (1.0 wt% ∼2.0 wt%V2O5) commonly show a T90 temperature window of 300–400 °C at a GHSV of 60,000 h−1 [26,27]. Therefore, FeVCe/SSn catalyst with a similar vanadium content via converting 1.5 wt% FeVO4 to 1.4 wt% V2O5 showed a wider activity temperature window (230–420 °C). 3.1.2 Water and sulfur resistance The resistance to H2O and SO2 of FeVCe/STi, FeVCe/SSn and FeVCe/SZr was tested, and the results are shown in Fig. 2. Since the NO x conversion of FeVCe/SSi was much lower than that of the other three samples, its resistance test was not performed. The NO x conversions of FeVCe/STi, FeVCe/SSn, and FeVCe/SZr stabilized at 100 %, 100 %, and 97.0 % at 275 °C, respectively. Then they decreased to different degrees after introducing 5 vol% of H2O and 100 ppm SO2. It was reported that the decrease of NO x conversion in the presence of H2O and SO2 may be due to the competitive adsorption between H2O, SO2 and NH3 or NO x , as well as the formation and deposition of ammonium sulfate or ammonium bisulfate and metal sulfates, which covered the active components and reduced the specific surface area of the catalyst, thus hindering the SCR reaction [11,28]. It was noteworthy that the NO x conversion of FeVCe/STi started to increase after H2O and SO2 were introduced for about 2 h. That may be attributed to the generation of new acid sites on FeVCe/STi sulfated by SO2, which improved the adsorption capacity for NH3 [29,30]. After the introduction of H2O and SO2 for about 24 h, the NO x conversions of FeVCe/SSn, FeVCe/STi, and FeVCe/SZr decreased to 90.0 %, 80.5 %, and 33.2 %, respectively. When H2O and SO2 were removed, their NO x conversions recovered to 99.2 %, 99.1 %, and 66.1 %, respectively. Additionally, their N2 selectivity was almost 100 % throughout the test. As a result, the toxic effects of H2O and SO2 on FeVCe/SSn and FeVCe/STi were almost reversible. The SCR performances of FeVCe/SSn and FeVCe/STi were stable. As shown in Fig. S2, the tolerance to 5 vol% H2O and 100 ppm SO2 of FeVCe sample was tested at 300 ℃ for 8 h, and its NO x conversion dropped from 97.3 % to 60.3 %. Therefore, sulfated SnO2 and TiO2 effectively enhanced the resistance to water and sulfur. Moreover, FeVCe/SSn exhibited the highest resistance to water and sulfur among them. The performances of collected published catalysts are shown in the Table S1 searched by the topics including NH3-SCR, low temperature, SO2 tolerance and support from 2022 to 2025 year. Compared with most of these catalysts, FeVO4/CeO2-nanosheet/sulfated-SnO2 catalyst shows high resistance to the coexistence of H2O and SO2 for a longer time, because its NO x conversion decreased from 100 % to 90.0 % after about 24 h and recovered to 99.2 %. The cooperation of FeVO4, CeO2-nanosheet and sulfated-SnO2 obtained a wide working temperature range of 227–422 °C with efficient NO x conversion beyond 90 % and N2 selectivity exceeding 97 %, and the high resistance to SO2 and H2O, retaining above 90 % for 24 h. 3.2 Phase analysis and element content 3.2.1 Phase analysis XRD patterns of FeVCe, SC-500 carriers and FeVCe/SC samples are shown in Fig. 3. Only the diffraction peaks matching face-centered cubic CeO2 (PDF # 34–0394) were observed on FeVCe. No diffraction peaks matching FeVO4 were observed in FeVCe and FeVCe/SC samples, because their FeVO4 contents were below the detection limit of XRD. In order to confirm the existence of FeVO4 in FeVCe and FeVCe/SC samples, FeVO4-P sample as a control was synthesized according to the same preparation method as theirs. The XRD pattern of FeVO4-P sample matched the standard pattern of triclinic FeVO4 (PDF #038–1372) as shown in Fig. S3, indicating that pure FeVO4 can form via the described reaction between Fe(NO3)3 and NH4VO3. The XRD pattern of STi-500 carrier showed diffraction peaks at 2θ = 25.3°, 37.8°, 48.1°, 53.9° and 55.1°, corresponding to anatase TiO2 (PDF # 01–078–2486). Besides, weak diffraction peaks at 27.5° and 41.2° were observed, which indicated the presence of a small amount of rutile TiO2 (PDF # 01–083–2242). A broad peak at 2θ = 22.2° was observed in the XRD pattern of SSi-500 carrier, attributed to tetragonal SiO2 (PDF # 29–0085). The XRD pattern of SSn-500 carrier showed clear diffraction peaks at 2θ = 26.5°, 33.8°, 51.7°, and 64.7°, matching tetragonal SnO2 (PDF # 01–077–0449). SZr-500 carrier had low crystallinity, but its diffraction peaks at 2θ = 30.3° and 50.6° were observed, corresponding to tetragonal ZrO2 (PDF # 01–079–1764). The characteristic peaks’ intensities of TiO2 and SiO2 on FeVCe/STi and FeVCe/SSi were reduced significantly compared to those of STi-500 and SSi-500. It suggested that the loaded FeVO4/CeO2 interacted with TiO2 and SiO2 carriers, inhibiting their grain growth. After FeVO4/CeO2 was loaded on sulfated TiO2, SiO2, SnO2, and ZrO2, the diffraction peaks corresponding to face-centered cubic CeO2 appeared at 2θ = 28.6°, 33.2°, 47.5°, 56.1°, and 59.0°. But these diffraction peaks showed different intensities, following the order of FeVCe/SSi > FeVCe/SZr >FeVCe/STi ≈ FeVCe/SSn. Generally, the lower intensity of the CeO2 diffraction peaks indicates higher dispersion of CeO2 on the surface of the carriers. This may be because the interaction between CeO2 and the carriers promoted the dispersion of CeO2 and inhibited its grain growth, which was conducive to SCR activity of the catalysts. Therefore, the lowest dispersion of FeVO4/CeO2 on FeVCe/SSi and the higher dispersion of FeVO4/CeO2 on FeVCe/SSn and FeVCe/STi contributed to the sequence of their NO x conversions. 3.2.2 Element content analysis The result of actual mass ratios of S/MO2, Fe/MO2 and Ce/MO2 (M represents Ti, Si, Sn and Zr) of FeVCe/SC catalysts determined by XRF are shown in Table S2. Although the sulfation and loading steps of different carriers were exactly the same, the S/MO2 mass ratios of FeVCe/SC varied, which indicated that the sulfation effects on these supports were different. And the S/MO2 mass ratio of FeVCe/SZr was the largest, suggesting that ZrO2 was easiest to be sulfated among them. The theoretical mass ratios of Fe/MO2 and Ce/MO2 in FeVCe/SC catalysts were 0.006 and 0.129, respectively. According to the XRD results, FeVO4 and CeO2 formed in FeVCe/SC catalysts. And, the actual Fe/MO2 and Ce/MO2 mass ratios of FeVCe/SC determined by XRF were very close to the corresponding theoretical mass ratios, and there were very little differences among FeVCe/SC samples, indicating that the preparation method was generally feasible. 3.3 Specific surface area and morphology 3.3.1 Specific surface area The specific surface area (SBET) and pore structure data of FeVCe/SC catalysts and the corresponding carriers are listed in Table 1. The catalysts with larger SBET and pore volume (Vp) can provide more active sites, which is favorable for the diffusion of reactants and product molecules and thus increases the catalytic activity [31]. Compared with STi-500, SSi-500 and SSn-500 samples, the SBET and Vp of FeVCe/STi, FeVCe/SSi and FeVCe/SSn declined in various extents, but the overall extents of decline were relatively small, indicating that the pores of carriers were slightly clogged by FeVO4 and CeO2. The SBET followed the order of FeVCe/SSi > FeVCe/SSn > FeVCe/STi > FeVCe/SZr. The small SBET and Vp of FeVCe/SZr were unfavorable to its catalytic activity. The SBET and Vp of FeVCe/SSi were the largest, but its NO x conversion was the lowest. Therefore, the sequence of SBET and Vp for FeVCe/SC catalysts was not consistent with that of their catalytic performance, which suggested that the specific surface area and pore volume were not the decisive factors and there were other important factors for the SCR activity of FeVCe/SC catalysts. 3.3.2 Morphology The morphology of these samples was investigated by SEM. The SEM images of FeVCe, FeVCe/SSn, FeVCe/STi, and FeVCe/SZr samples are shown in Fig. 4, and that of FeVCe/SSi are shown in Fig.S4. As shown in Fig. 4(a), FeVCe sample displayed multilayer lamellar accumulation with FeVO4 nanoparticles loaded on CeO2 nanosheets. In FeVCe/SSn sample (Fig. 4(b)), the bulking thickness of nanoparticles possibly including FeVO4 and sulfated SnO2 on CeO2 nanosheets increased and more sulfated SnO2 nanoparticles piled up around CeO2 nanosheets. The similar morphology was observed in FeVCe/SZr sample but the sulfated ZrO2 nanoparticles stacked more closely. The sizes of nanoparticles in FeVCe/STi and FeVCe/SSi samples were bigger and then only the pictures of the nanoparticles loaded on large CeO2 nanosheets were captured occasionally. It was hard to observe small and uniform CeO2 nanosheets, possibly because they were covered by those sulfated TiO2 and SiO2 nanoparticles. Among the four catalysts with supports, FeVCe/SSn sample displayed the most uniform morphology, indicated the well dispersion of FeVO4 and CeO2 nanosheets. 3.4 Chemical state of surface elements The effect of the carriers on the chemical state of the elements in the FeVCe catalyst was investigated by XPS. Fig. S5(a) demonstrates the XPS spectra of Ti 2p, Si 2p, Sn 3d and Zr 3d on FeVCe/SC catalysts. Two peaks at 182.7 eV and 185.1 eV in the Zr 3d spectrum of FeVCe/SZr were assigned to Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 spin orbits of Zr4+ [32]. The Sn 3d spectrum of FeVCe/SSn exhibited two peaks at 487.2 eV and 495.7 eV, which corresponded to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 spin orbits of Sn4+, respectively [33]. The peak at 103.7 eV in the Si 2p spectrum of FeVCe/SSi was a characteristic peak of SiO2. The Ti 2p spectrum of FeVCe/STi showed two characteristic peaks at 459.0 eV and 464.6 eV, which were assigned to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 spin orbits of Ti4+ [34]. Fig. S5(b) shows the S 2p XPS spectra of FeVCe/SC catalysts. Peak-differentiating and imitating of the S 2p spectra of FeVCe/STi, FeVCe/SSn, and FeVCe/SZr yielded two peaks located at around 169.0 eV and 170.0 eV, which were attributed to S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2 spin orbits of SO4 2-, respectively. And the S 2p spectrum of FeVCe/SSi showed a peak located at 168.8 eV corresponding to SO4 2-. Therefore, the surface S element of FeVCe/SC catalyst existed as SO4 2- [13,26]. The Fe 2p XPS spectra of FeVCe/SC and FeVCe catalysts are shown in Fig. S6(a). The peaks located at around 724 eV and 710.8 eV in the spectra of FeVCe, FeVCe/SZr, FeVCe/SSi and FeVCe/STi were assigned to the 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 orbit of Fe3+ [35,36]. For FeVCe/SSn, the peaks of Fe 2p overlapped with a peak of Sn 3p. And after the peak fitting, a peak at 712.6 eV was attributed to the Fe 2p3/2 spin orbit of Fe3+ [37,38]. The V 2p3/2 XPS spectra of FeVCe/SC and FeVCe catalysts are shown in Fig. 5(a). For FeVCe catalysts, V 2p3/2 spectrum was fitted into two peaks corresponding to V5+ (517.2 eV) and V4+ (516.3 eV) [39]. Surface V also existed as V5+ and V4+ in all FeVCe/SC catalysts. Relative to that of FeVCe, the V 2p3/2 characteristic peaks of FeVCe/SZr shifted significantly to the higher binding energy indicating the decrease in electron cloud density of V. That may be caused by the strong electron-withdrawing effect of a large amount of SO4 2-, because the S content of FeVCe/SZr was the highest among them confirmed by XRF results and SO covalent bonds in sulfates attracted electrons from the connected metal atoms according to reported studies [19,40]. Compared to FeVCe, the proportion of V5+ in FeVCe/SC catalysts decreased. Among them, the proportion of V5+ in FeVCe/STi and FeVCe/SSn decreased the most, which indicated that the extranuclear electron cloud density of V increased in FeVCe/STi and FeVCe/SSn. Combined with the XRD results, the sulfated carriers interacted with the active component FeVO4, promoted its dispersion and inhibited its grain growth, which resulted in more structural defects and weakened interactions between V and ligand oxygen atoms. Fig. 5(b) shows the Ce 3d XPS spectra of FeVCe/SC and FeVCe catalysts. The Ce 3d XPS spectra can be fitted to eight peaks. For FeVCe catalysts, the peaks labeled as v (882.4 eV), u (900.9 eV), v″ (889.0 eV), u″ (907.4 eV), v‴ (898.3 eV) and u‴ (916.6 eV) were attributed to Ce4+, and the characteristic peaks labeled as v′ (884.9 eV) and u′ (902.8 eV) were attributed to Ce3+ [25,26]. The above results indicated that all prepared catalysts contained Ce3+ and Ce4+. The redox cycle between Ce3+ and Ce4+ can promote the NH3-SCR reaction, and the presence of Ce3+ is accompanied by the generation of oxygen vacancies, which is an important factor for ensuring the excellent redox properties of cerium-containing catalysts [41,42]. The presence of Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies creates an imbalance in charge and induces the crystals to produce unsaturated chemical bonds, thus enhancing the chemisorption of free oxygen on the catalyst surface, which is conducive to the improvement of SCR activity [36]. The atomic ratio of Ce3+ and Ce4+ was calculated by the area ratio of Ce3+ and Ce4+ peaks after peak fitting, and the results are shown in Table 2. Among FeVCe/SC, FeVCe/SSn had the highest ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+), followed by FeVCe/STi, which was consistent with the rule of their NO x conversions. Combined with the XRD results, it may be because the interaction between CeO2 and sulfated SnO2 or TiO2 increased the dispersion of CeO2 and thus reduced its crystallinity, producing more Ce3+ defect sites. The O 1 s XPS spectra of FeVCe/SC and FeVCe catalysts are shown in Fig. S6(b). In the O 1 s XPS spectrum of FeVCe, the peaks at 529.6 eV, 531.0 eV and 532.0 eV were attributed to lattice oxygen, surface hydroxyl oxygen, and weakly adsorbed oxygen species, respectively [26,43]. Because of the various peak positions of lattice oxygen species from FeVO4, CeO2 and sulfated supports, the O 1 s XPS spectra of different FeVCe/SC samples varied greatly, which was described detailedly in the supplementary material. Therefore, it was difficult to obtain the clear information about the difference in surface active oxygen ratios of four FeVCe/SC samples from their O 1 s XPS spectra. 3.5 Redox property H2-TPR experiments can be used to test the redox capacity of catalyst samples. Fig. 6 shows the H2-TPR curves of FeVCe and FeVCe/SC catalysts. Two obvious reduction peaks of FeVCe catalysts were located at 426 °C and 478 °C, which were attributed to the peak of Fe3+ reduced to Fe(3-δ)+, and the overlapping peak of Fe(3-δ)+ reduced to Fe2+ and surface V5+ reduced to V4+, respectively. The reduction peaks of Ce4+ to Ce3+ on the surface of CeO2 nanosheets were wide, and overlapped with the above reduction peaks [44–47]. FeVCe/STi, FeVCe/SSi, and FeVCe/SZr showed a high H2 reduction peak at 544 °C, 568 °C and 649 °C, respectively, which might be the reduction peaks of metal sulfates [48–51]. For FeVCe/SSn, the peak at 637 °C was attributed to the overlap of reduction from sulfate, bulk Sn4+ and surface Sn2+ [52], while the peaks at 315 °C and 431 °C were attributed to the overlap of the reduction peaks of surface Fe3+, V5+ and Ce4+. In addition, as reported in the literature [53], SnO2 exhibited a wide reduction peak of surface Sn4+ to Sn2+ at near 340 °C, which overlapped with the above reduction peaks. Compared to that of FeVCe, the starting temperature and peaks attributed to surface Fe3+, V5+ and Ce4+ of FeVCe/STi, FeVCe/SSi, and FeVCe/SZr all shifted to a higher temperature, indicating that sulfated TiO2, SiO2 and ZrO2 inhibited the redox property of FeVCe, which is one of the reasons for the decrease of their NO x conversions at low temperature. The excessively high redox capacity may worsen the N2 selectivity of FeVO4/CeO2 nanosheet [25]. Therefore, the inhibition of the redox ability by sulfated TiO2, and ZrO2 enhanced the N2 selectivity of FeVO4/CeO2 nanosheet at high temperatures to some extent. The redox ability of FeVCe/SC catalyst followed the sequence of FeVCe/SSn > FeVCe/STi > FeVCe/SZr > FeVCe/SSi, in accordance with the results of CeO2 crystallinity and dispersion. The starting temperature of reduction peak for FeVCe/SSn was the lowest, indicating that FeVCe/SSn was easiest to be reduced among them. Moreover, the reduction peak area below 500 °C of FeVCe/SSn was the largest, indicating that the active species involved in the redox reaction were abundant in FeVCe/SSn. This might be due to the formation of more surface oxygen species resulting from Ce-O-Sn electron interaction [54]. Consequently, FeVCe/SSn showed the strongest redox capacity among them, which contributed to the superior NO x conversion and resistance to water and sulfur. 3.6 Surface acidity 3.6.1 NH3-TPD analysis The NO x conversion of the SCR catalyst is related to the adsorption amount of NH3 affected by the surface acidity. Thus, NH3-TPD experiments were performed on FeVCe and FeVCe/SC catalysts. The peak-fitted NH3-TPD profiles are shown in Fig. 7 and the direct comparison of original NH3-TPD profiles is shown in Fig. S7. Each NH3-TPD profile was fitted into three desorption bands centered at around 280 °C, 350 °C and 460 °C, assigned to weak, moderate-intensity and strong acid sites, respectively [21,55]. The integral area of the NH3-TPD curves can indicate the relative number of acid sites on the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7, the integral area of the NH3-TPD curves was in the order of FeVCe/SSi (3.08) > FeVCe/SSn (2.29) > FeVCe/STi (1.40) > FeVCe (1.00) > FeVCe/SZr (0.68), with that of FeVCe as a benchmark. The ratios of different kinds of acid sites on these samples are shown in Table S3. Except FeVCe/SZr, the sulfated supports increased the total acid sites plainly. And, all these supports increased the ratios of strong acid sites on FeVCe/SC samples, especially sulfated TiO2 and ZrO2. Compared with FeVCe, the surface acidity of both FeVCe/SSi and FeVCe/SSn catalysts improved significantly. In addition, sulfated SnO2 largely increased the ratio of weak acid sites. In order to exclude the effect of specific surface area on the number of acid sites, the relative specific acid amounts of the catalysts were calculated via dividing the integral area of NH3-TPD curve by specific surface area. And the order of their relative values with that of FeVCe (1.00) as a benchmark was FeVCe/SZr (2.14) > FeVCe/SSn (1.66) > FeVCe/SSi (1.61) > FeVCe/STi (1.54), which agreed with the sequence of their sulfur contents shown in Table S2. So, the fewest acid sites for FeVCe/SZr resulted from its smallest specific surface area. The large SBET of FeVCe/SSi contributed to the most surface acid sites on it. Therefore, except FeVCe/SZr and FeVCe/SSi, the SBET of other samples did not play a decisive role in the amount of surface acidity. The above results indicated that the surface sulfates played a key role in providing acid sites for the FeVCe/SC catalysts. Although FeVCe/SSi had the most acid sites among FeVCe/SC, the poor redox properties limited its SCR performance. And the sequence of surface acidity for FeVCe/SSn, FeVCe/STi and FeVCe/SZr was consistent with that of NO x conversion and resistance to water and sulfur, indicating that the surface acidity was an important factor for their SCR performance and the strongest surface acidity of FeVCe/SSn contributed to its best performance among the three samples. 3.6.2 Pyridine-IR analysis The peaks of pyridine (Py) absorption obtained at 200 °C were considered the peaks of pyridine adsorbed on the total acid sites, while those at 400 °C were regarded as that on the strong acid sites. Py-IR spectra over FeVCe/SSn, FeVCe/STi, FeVCe/SZr, FeVCe/SSi and FeVCe samples at 200 °C are provided in Fig. 8(A), and that at room temperature and 400 °C are shown in Fig. S8. The peaks around 1445, 1575 and 1605 cm−1 corresponded to the coordinated pyridine on Lewis acid sites, while the peaks around 1540 and 1639 cm−1 were attributed to pyridine adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites. The peak near 1491 cm−1 was assigned to the pyridine adsorbed on Lewis and Brønsted acid sites [56,57]. The intensities of these peaks declined from room temperature to 400 °C, but they still existed at 400 °C, indicating the presence of strong Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, especially Lewis acid sites. The corresponding ratios of Brønsted/Lewis acid sites (B/L ratio) indicated with the peaks around 1540 cm−1 and 1445 cm−1 and the amounts of acid sites from NH3-TPD and Py-IR results of all samples are displayed in Fig. 8(B). The calculated B/L ratio over FeVCe/SZr sample might be not accurate due to its low intensity of peaks. Based on the results of NH3-TPD and Py-IR, FeVCe sample possessed plentiful Lewis acid sites and small amount of Brønsted acid sites. Compared with FeVCe, sulfated SnO2 and SiO2 increased both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites plainly, and sulfated TiO2 mainly increased Lewis acid sites in accordance with its increased ratios of strong acid sites in NH3-TPD curve. All four sulfated supports increased the ratios of Brønsted acid sites and sulfated SnO2 increased the most corresponding to its increased ratios of weak acid sites in NH3-TPD curve. Based on the results of NH3-TPD, Py-IR and the references [18,54], the sulfation on SnO2 contributed to the increase of Brønsted acid sites and SnO2 provided strong Lewis acid sites on FeVCe/SSn catalyst. 3.7 In situ DRIFTS analysis The results of SCR performance tests and a series of characterizations showed that FeVCe/SSn catalyst possessed the optimal NO x conversion, water and sulfur tolerance, strong surface acidity and high redox capacity. Therefore, the adsorption behaviors and transient reaction processes of NH3, NO + O2 and SO2 + O2 gases on the FeVCe/SSn catalyst were investigated by in situ DRIFTS, in order to explore its active adsorption species and reaction mechanism. 3.7.1 Reaction between adsorbed NH3 species with NO and O2 The in situ DRIFTS experiments were as follows. First, FeVCe/SSn was pretreated in N2 at 400 °C for 40 min, and cooled down to 250 °C to collect the background. Second, 500 ppm NH3 was passed into the sample chamber for 30 min followed by N2 purging for 20 min (Fig. S9). Third, 500 ppm NO + 5 % O2 continuously flowed over the sample for 30 min, and infrared spectra of the sample during this process were collected and the results are shown in Fig. 9. NH3 is chemically adsorbed on the catalyst surface in two basic forms: NH3 is coordinated on a coordinatively unsaturated metal cation as the Lewis acid site (L-NH3); NH3 is protonated to NH4 + on hydroxyl (-OH) as the Brønsted acid site (B-NH4 +) [58].As shown in Fig. S9, after the introduction of NH3 for 3 min, the peaks attributed to the asymmetric bending vibration of B-NH4 + [30] and the symmetric bending vibration of L-NH3 [33] appeared at 1390 cm−1 and 1282 cm−1, respectively. Besides, the peaks at 1358 cm−1 and 1321 cm−1, attributed to amides (-NH2), appeared after 15 min [26]. The peak at 1447 cm−1 was attributed to the symmetric bending vibration of B-NH4 + [59]. As time went by, the intensity of all peaks increased gradually and were stable after N2 purging for 20 min. Furthermore, compared with in situ DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption on 10 %FeV/CeO2-nanosheet [25], the high peak at 1390 cm−1 attributed to B-NH4 + on FeVCe/SSn catalyst suggested that sulfation can dramatically increase the Brønsted acid sites [30]. Combining NH3-TPD and Py-IR with in situ DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption results, the sulfated SnO2 significantly enhanced the surface acidity on FeVCe/SSn catalyst, especially Brønsted acid sites from SO4 2-. As shown in Fig. 9, after inletting NO + O2, the peaks of adsorbed NH3 species at 1282 cm−1 (L-NH3), 1358 cm−1 (amide species), and 1390 cm−1 and 1447 cm−1 (B-NH4 +) overlapped with the peaks of some adsorbed NO x species and therefore their peak intensity increased with time. In addition, a new peak attributed to NO- species appeared at 1157 cm−1 [59]. However, the intensity of the peak at 1321 cm−1 assigned to the amide species decreased with time and disappeared after 5 min, indicating that the SCR reaction on FeVCe/SSn catalyst followed the E-R mechanism: the adsorbed ammonia species reacted with gas-phase NO x to form N2 and H2O. 3.7.2 Reaction between adsorbed NO x species and NH3 The experiment process was similar to that described in preceding paragraph and the only difference was the sequence of inletting NO + O2 and NH3. Fig. S10 shows in situ DRIFTS spectra of NO + O2 adsorption over FeVCe/SSn with time. When NO + O2 was introduced into the sample chamber, the adsorption peaks appeared immediately at 1560, 1477 and 1394 cm−1 attributed to bidentate nitrate [55], monodentate nitrate [26], and trans-hyponitrites(trans-N2O2 2-) [59]. The peak attributed to trans-N2O2 2- at 1427 cm−1 appeared after 5 min, and the intensity of above peaks gradually increased with time. After N2 purging for 20 min, the intensity of peaks at 1560, 1477 and 1427 cm−1 remained almost unchanged, while the peaks of cis-N2O2 2- at 1338 cm−1 and free NO3 - at 1380 cm−1 [60] increased in intensity, which might be converted from other instable adsorption species of NO x , accompanying by the decrease in peak intensity at 1394 cm−1. As shown in Fig. 10, after introducing NH3, almost all of the peaks of adsorbed NO x species including bidentate nitrate (1560 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1477 cm−1), trans-N2O2 2- (1394 cm−1), free NO3 - (1380 cm−1) and cis-N2O2 2- (1338 cm−1) disappeared after 5 min, while the peaks associated with the adsorbed NH3 species started to appear. As time went by, the peaks of adsorbed B-NH4 + (1381 and 1447 cm−1), L-NH3 species (1282 cm−1) and amide species (1358 and 1321 cm−1) strengthened gradually. That observed reaction process suggested that the SCR reaction on FeVCe/SSn catalyst followed the L-H mechanism: adsorbed ammonia species reacted with adsorbed nitrate species to form N2 and H2O. To sum up, the SCR reaction on FeVCe/SSn catalyst followed both E-R mechanism and L-H mechanism. 3.7.3 DRIFTS of SO2 + O2 adsorption FeVCe/SSn possessed a high water and sulfur resistance. Therefore, the SO2 adsorption performance of FeVCe/SSn catalyst and FeVCe as a control was investigated. 500 ppm SO2 + 5 % O2 was introduced into the reaction cell for 30 min after the transient reaction between adsorbed NO x species and NH3 followed by 20 min N2 purge. The results are shown in Fig. 11. The adsorption behavior of SO2 + O2 on FeVCe and FeVCe/SSn catalysts were different significantly. As shown in Fig. 11 (a), many new strong peaks were observed at 1369, 1303, 1106 and 986 cm−1 after the adsorption of SO2 + O2 on FeVCe sample, and they were assigned to surface sulfate species [25]. However, the spectrum of FeVCe/SSn catalyst changed little after inletting SO2 + O2, suggesting that the adsorption of SO2 was very weak on it. Therefore, the adsorption of SO2 on FeVCe/SSn catalyst was suppressed, because the sulfated SnO2 significantly enhanced its surface acidity. That was conducive to the enhancement of its sulfur-resistant performance. 3.7.4 The proposed mechanism on FeVCe/SSn catalyst The proposed NH3-SCR reaction mechanism and anti-poisoning mechanism on FeVCe/SSn catalyst are shown in Fig. 12. The in situ DRIFTS results show that the SCR reaction over FeVCe/SSn catalyst is governed by a synergistic Eley–Rideal and Langmuir–Hinshelwood pathway. Therefore, the adsorption and activation of NH3 and NO on it is crucial to the SCR reaction activity, which is affected by surface acidity and redox properties. SEM images and XRD results display the higher dispersion of FeVO4 and CeO2 nanosheet among sulfated SnO2 nanoparticles in FeVCe/SSn catalyst compared with other FeVCe/SC catalysts. Moreover, the nanosheet structure of CeO2 not only contributes to the uniform distribution but also benefits to the interaction between them. Based on the analysis of the TPR, XPS, NH3-TPD, and Py-IR results and related references [18,25], FeVO4 is the most active component, providing both redox sites and acid sites, while CeO2 nanosheet possesses strong oxygen storage capacity and excellent redox properties. Moreover, SnO2 owns profuse intrinsic oxygen vacancies and strong Lewis acid sites, and sulfation (SO4 2-) further generated abundant Brønsted acid sites on sulfated SnO2. The cooperation between sulfated SnO2, FeVO4 and CeO2 nanosheet further enhances the surface acidity significantly, and increases the oxygen vacancies accompanied by Ce3+, which contribute to the adsorption and activation of NH3 and NO [25,61].Therefore, FeVCe/SSn catalyst possesses both excellent redox properties and plentiful acid sites, which is favorable to its best SCR performance. In addition, according to the in situ DRIFTS result of SO2 adsorption, the adsorption of SO2 on FeVCe/SSn catalyst is suppressed compared with that on FeVCe, probably due to the significantly enhanced surface acidity by the sulfated SnO2 and the reduced oxidation of SO2 due to the low content of FeVO4 and CeO2 in FeVCe/SSn catalyst. Therefore, FeVCe/SSn catalyst performs the high resistance to SO2. 4 Conclusions FeVO4/CeO2-nanosheet was loaded on sulfated TiO2, SiO2, SnO2, and ZrO2 respectively, and the obvious support effect was observed among them. Their NO x conversion and resistance to H2O and SO2 followed the order of FeVCe/SSn > FeVCe/STi > FeVCe/SZr > FeVCe/SSi. The limited performance of FeVCe/SSi demonstrates that high surface area and acidity is insufficient to counterbalance for deficient redox capacity; for the other three catalysts redox ability, acid-site density and surface area scale directly with ranking. Therefore, FeVCe/SSn catalyst possessed both excellent redox properties and plentiful acid sites. The optimum carrier, sulfated SnO2, strongly anchors FeVO4 and CeO2 while suppressing CeO2 crystallisation, enriching Ce3+/oxygen-vacancies and offering abundant Lewis (Sn4+) and superacidic Brønsted (SO4 2-) sites. These features enable fast NH3 activation and NO reduction via concurrent Eley–Rideal and Langmuir–Hinshelwood pathways, conferring the widest operating window and superior SO2/H2O durability. coredata.dc:description: The support effect of sulfated SnO2, TiO2, ZrO2, and SiO2 on FeVO4/CeO2-nanosheet was systematically investigated in this work. Among them, FeVO4/CeO2-nanosheet/sulfated-SnO2 (FeVCe/SSn) catalyst exhibited the widest operating temperature window (227–422 °C) with efficient NO x conversion beyond 90 % and N2 selectivity exceeding 97 %, as well as superior resistance to SO2 and H2O (above 90 % activity retention for 24 h). The catalytic performance followed the order: FeVCe/SSn > FeVCe/STi > FeVCe/SZr > FeVCe/SSi, which aligns well with their redox properties. FeVCe/SSn presents the best redox ability and the second highest surface acidity. Owing to the most pronounced interaction of sulfated SnO2 with FeVO4 and CeO2 nanosheet, surface oxygen vacancies were significantly increased; simultaneously, sulfated SnO2 provided abundant superacidic Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites inherent to SnO2. This synergistic effect enhanced NH3 adsorption/activation and suppressed SO2 adsorption, thereby improving SCR activity and SO2/H2O resistance. The plausible mechanistic studies reveal that the SCR reaction over FeVCe/SSn is governed by a synergistic Eley–Rideal and Langmuir–Hinshelwood pathway. This study demonstrates that the rational design of acid-site density and the interfacial synergy between support and active phase constitute a feasible design principle for SCR catalysts that simultaneously afford a broad temperature window and high SO2/H2O durability.
